text: An immense movie palace with gilded carvings and three balconies. It looks like an opera house. The members of t audience excitedly take their seats. They are dressed in black tie and evening clothes. Flashbulbs go off, the lig dim, and a spotlight shines on a dark, thin man with glas He says in Italian (subtitled in English):

Ladies and gentlemen, we are very pleased to welcome you to the world premiere of Part 1 of the newest film from a great favorite of ours here at Loquasto, Mr. Steve Zissou. A brief Q & A will immediately follow the screening. Thank you very much. The man leaves the stage as the spotlight goes off. The a applauds. The words Loquasto International Film Festival projected against a gold silk curtain. The gold curtain o red curtain beneath it rises, and the film begins. The first title slides into the center of the frame again black background. It is accompanied by a spinning globe l
Oseary Drakoulias presents

An underwater shot of five divers approaching in pale blu wet suits with navy stripes down the sides. They wear red flippers and have yellow aqualungs strapped to their back gold barracuda with black teeth swims by and swallows a translucent starfish with a live shrimp in its stomach. The next title appears in red:

A shirtless man in a knitted red cap standing alone on th deck of a ship. He is fifty. He has silver hair and a bea with curls. A flock of gulls descends from above and fill the frame. He looks up at them and laughs. The image free
with Steve Zissou  The image un-freezes, and the birds fly away.
A small Mediterranean island. There is a marina in the foreground and a collection of houses and laboratory buildings in the background.
Adventure No. 12: “The Jaguar Shark” (Part 1)
Zissou stands next to a window in an office overlooking t compound and the ocean beyond it. He wears a brown suit w pinstripes and a thin black tie. He speaks calmly into th camera:

The Oubyamywe Peninsula. A remote and fascinating region teeming with extraordinary marine life. Zissou pulls down a chain and lowers a map from an appara mounted on the wall. He points with a pencil to a spot on Western coast of Africa.
We chose its mysterious waters as the Belafonte’s next destination. Zissou sits at his desk with charts and graphs in front o him and a model of his ship, the Belafonte, at his side.
In preparation for our voyage, the members of Team Zissou gathered at my oceanographic observatory here on Pescespada Island. The camera slowly zooms in on Zissou.
This was to be our most ambitious adventure to date -- and, ultimately, a tragic one.

The crew of the Belafonte sets to work on-board the ship. They wear pale blue swimsuits with navy stripes down the sides, long-sleeved aquamarine polyester shirts with epa and Team Zissou logos on them, and red knitted caps. Each a Glock pistol in a holster on his belt. Zissou introduce them in voice-over.
Our team included: cuT TO: A heavy-set, slightly hunched man with a shaved head and bull’s neck but soft eyes. He directs the lowering of a m sub suspended from a crane.
Esteban du Plantier, 66, Chief Diver. Our senior statesman, my closest colleague for twenty-seven years.
A tall, rakish man holding a pair of sunglasses in his mo He checks the air pressure gauges on an oxygen tank.
Klaus Daimler, 40, Engineer. Calm, collected, German.
A spindly Indian man with a long beard and a red turban. puts a 16mm camera onto his shoulder and adjusts the focu
Vikram Ray, 28, Cameraman. Born on the Ganges.
A young Japanese-American man in a wet suit treading wate beside the ship. A dolphin surfaces next to him. He strok it.
Bobby Ogata, 22, Frogman. Can hold his breath for seven minutes, thirty-eight seconds.
A weathered, aristocratic-looking man wearing headphones. leans over the railing with a microphone on a boom.
Renzo Pietro, 45, Editor/Sound Man.
A very skinny man with goggles on top of his head sitting behind a microscope. He holds up a slide and squints at i
Vladimir Wolodarsky, 33, Physicist/ Original Score Composer.
A wavy-haired girl with freckles, topless in a bikini. Sh clicks off a stopwatch and writes something on a clipboar
Anne-Marie Sakowitz, 25, Script-girl.
A dark-skinned Brazilian man. He holds a burning flare ov his head. Sparks shower all around.
Pelé dos Santos, 30, Safety Expert.
A beautiful woman in her late forties standing at the pro the ship smoking a brown cigarette. Her hair is wet, long and black, parted on the side with a clip in it. She wear white bathrobe.
Eleanor Zissou, my wife/Vice-President of the Zissou Society.
Seven slightly-built college students dressed in Team Zis T-shirts and camp shorts walk up the gangplank carrying extremely heavy equipment.
We had also invited seven marine science students from the University of North Alaska to accompany us as unpaid interns in exchange for school credit.
The ship is anchored at sea in open waters. A narrator announces:
October 12. Entry in the logbook of the Belafonte by Captain Zissou.
Zissou and Esteban pose in their diving gear looking into camera with their arms around each other’s shoulders. Zis kisses Esteban on the cheek. Esteban breaks a saltine in and gives Zissou half.
Esteban and I explore the blue reefs beyond the peninsula.

Zissou and Esteban swimming underwater through a bright b atoll. A school of gently glowing pink fish moves past th ZzISSOU (V.0.) Fluorescent snapper unexpectedly appear in the shallows -- extremely rare at this depth. Zissou captures one of the fish with a cloth net. It glow pink beneath the thin fabric. Zissou and Esteban laugh through their mouthpieces, and bubbles cascade all around them.
Klaus and Ogata look nervously over the side of the ship. water beneath them bubbles violently and begins to turn r Klaus yells to Ogata:

Where's your gun? Ogata hesitates. Zissou surfaces suddenly. There is blood his wet suit. He rips off his mask and gasps. He looks disoriented and wildly agitated. He points into the camer and shouts with his voice raspy and cracking:
Is that rolling? Vikram!
Steve? What’s happening? Where’s --

Tail slate! Second sticks! Take one! Encounter with highly abnormal shark-like fish at least ten meters in length with unfamiliar dorsal features and spots all over it! I shot it dorsally with a homing dart! Esteban was eaten! Check the scanning monitor and start tracking it before it dives too --
(stunned) Esteban was bitten?
(pause) Eaten!
(shocked) Is he dead?
(emphatically) Esteban was eaten! Check the scanning monitor before it goes too deep!
(confused) Was he -- he was swallowed whole?

(hesitates) No! Chewed! Check the scanning monitor! Ogata is filming with a second camera. He puts it down an starts to run inside. Klaus notices that Zissou’s eyes ar pinned and blood-shot, and there is a green film around h lips. He says to himself:

He’s got hydrogen psychosis. Crazy-eye! (yelling to Ogata) Wait! Get him out of the fucking water! There’s something down there! Klaus and Ogata scramble down a ladder to help Zissou. Kl says loudly but calmly:
Steve, we think you’ve got crazy-eye! Don’t try to -- Zissou suddenly loses control of himself, jerking around screaming hysterically toward the water:
Esteban! Esteban! Esteban! Esteban!

Zissou sitting in the audience viewing the film. He wears red pin in the lapel of his tuxedo. A gold legion of hono medal hangs around his neck. There is a diamond star earr in his left earlobe. His face looks hollow, and his eyes dark and sunken. He watches expressionlessly. Eleanor sits beside him looking down at the floor. She ha her hair in a French twist and wears a sleek, silver dres and pearls.

Zissou and the director of the festival sitting at a tabl stage after the screening. The audience has thinned out significantly. The director of the festival points to a m in the orchestra. The man asks a question in Italian. The director of the festival translates for Zissou:
Was it a deliberate choice never to show the jaguar shark?
No, I dropped the camera. The audience laughs. The director of the festival transla Zissou's answer into Italian, and the audience laughs aga

Why are they laughing? The audience laughs. An exceptionally clean-cut man in his late twenties sits the front row of the highest tier of the balconies. He ha short blond hair, parted neatly on the side. He wears an airline pilot’s uniform with a Colonel Sanders-type strin tie and has his cap tucked under his arm. He is Ned Plimp Ned raises his hand, and the director of the festival po to him. Ned speaks with the accent of a deep Southerner:
What’s next for Team Zissou? Zissou shields his eyes from the lights with his hand and squints at Ned. He says evenly:

Well, that was only Part 1. It’s a cliff- hanger. Now I’m going to hunt down that shark or whatever it is, and, hopefully, kill it. I’m not sure how, maybe dynamite. A murmur goes through the audience. Some of them have alr begun to gather their things and make their way to the ex The director of the festival looks confused.
You don’t know what it is?
No. I’ve never seen anything like it in my life.
You said it was a jaguar shark. That’s the title of the film.

He was coming right at us. I said the first two words that came into my head. The director of the festival hesitates. Zissou points to young woman in the audience with her hand in the air. She asks a question in French. The director of the festival translates for Zissou:
It's an endangered species, at most. What would be the scientific purpose of killing it? Silence. Zissou answers as if it goes without saying:
Revenge. The director of the festival translates Zissou’s answer i French.

The lobby of the theatre. A terrace opens onto the harbor and the Belafonte is anchored in the distance. The member the audience flood out of the auditorium. Zissou walks wi the director of the festival at his side. An elderly man dressed in a safari jacket follows, stalking them. A pale angular woman wearing bright red lipstick and a complex, asymmetrical hat intercepts them.
Bravo! What fun!
Steve, I'd like to introduce you to Antonia Cook, the new head of the film society. The woman clasps Zissou'’s hands.
You must be so excited! ZISsoU (distracted) I hope so. You thought it went OK?
No, congratulations. Seriously.
Thanks. I wish it didn’t need the seriously, but --
Hm? (suddenly pensive) Well, I just don’t think they knew what to make of it.

Yeah. Oh, well. Fuck it, I guess. Zissou pushes through the crowded room. He comes upon a seventy-year-old Englishman with white hair, oiled and co straight back, and large, round sunglasses. He wears a bl suit, a white shirt, and a white tie. He is Oseary Drakoulias. Drakoulias takes hold of Zissou’s arm and say enthusiastically:
Steve --  10.
(to himself) It’s a shit turnout tonight.

(hesitates) I believe you know Larry Amin, Chairman of Saudifilm. Drakoulias motions to a small Arab man standing next to h The man has a neat, white beard and a military-style bere with a jewel pinned into it. Zissou nods restlessly.
Oh, yeah. Hi.
Larry and I were just discussing our financial predicament. Shall the three of us ride out to the party together?
Why? Has Larry got that kind of spending bread to invest? A pair of photographers interrupts:

Captain Zissou, can we get a shot of you and Captain Hennessey? Zissou frowns. He turns and sees an immaculately dressed in black tie and chromium-framed eyeglasses with the same medal around his neck and pin in his lapel that Zissou we He also has several additional ribbons and badges, and he holds a gold-plated award statuette of a barracuda. He is surrounded by a Japanese television crew. He is Alistair Hennessey. Zissou says to the photographers:
Make it quick. Zissou and Hennessey stand shoulder-to-shoulder for the photographers. The elderly man in the safari jacket stand among them, watching. Flashbulbs start popping.
Hello, Steven. How are things going with your -- what are you calling it? Leopard fish?
Jaguar shark.  1i.
(thrilled) Jaguar shark, exactly! I love it! (gravely) Tell me something. Does it actually exist? Pause. Zissou smiles slightly.
Well, you know, Allie. I don’t want to give away the ending. Hennessey nods and smiles.
Good man. Here comes our girl. Hennessey motions to Eleanor approaching from across the room. He kisses her on both cheeks.
You're the most ravishing creature I’ve seen in my life.
Hello, Skinny. Eleanor points to one of Hennessey’s medals.
Is that a new merit badge?
(pleased) As a matter of fact, it is. I just became a knight in Portugal. The presidente --
(interrupting) Don’t be nice to Allie. He’s my nemesis. Hennessey laughs. He kisses Eleanor again and rejoins his Japanese television crew. Eleanor takes Zissou by the arm walks with him.
How could you lay that slick faggot?
Well, I was in love with him, at the time.  12.
{sighs) Yeah, I know. He’s charismatic.
How are you feeling?
(strangely) I'm right on the edge. I don’t know what comes next. Eleanor looks into Zissou’s eyes. She frowns. She opens h handbag and digs inside. She says to Zissou:
Wait here. I’11 be right back. Eleanor walks away. A tall, beautiful African girl comes and stops squarely in front of Zissou. Zissou looks nervo
I just wanted to say hello. Hi.
(relieved) Hey, baby. Zissou starts to kiss the African girl on the cheek. She blocks him with her arm and feints away. Zissou looks surprised.

I said I wanted to say hello. I didn’t say I wanted you to touch me. Silence. Eleanor returns with a glass of whiskey and two Valiums for Zissou. She and the African girl stare at eac other. Zissou points to Bleanor.
I'm here with my wife. Eleanor, this is Mandeeza. Mandeeza --

Do we really want to put me through this? Pause. Zissou shakes his head. Eleanor hands him the whis and the pills. She and the African girl walk swiftly away different directions. Zissou sees the elderly man in the safari jacket spying on him from behind a lamp. The elder Man moves away. Zissou swallows the pills and drinks the whiskey. He goes over to a television set on a pedestal.  13. It shows him being interviewed on an English talk show. Esteban sits beside him. The host says:
People say Eleanor is the brains behind Team Zissou. What is Steve? Zissou hesitates. Esteban interrupts slyly:

He’s the Zissou. Esteban shrugs. Zissou smiles identically on television and watching it. reaches out and touches Esteban’s face on the screen. Sta crackles at his fingertip. He turns away from the televis set and looks across the room blankly. Klaus brings over ten-year-old German boy with bronze~colored skin and near white hair in a buzz-cut. He wears lederhosen. He carries small plastic bag filled with water.
Steve, this is my little nephew, Werner. He wanted to meet you. Zissou pats the boy on the head.
How you doing, Werner? Werner holds out the plastic bag.
He brought you a present. Zissou takes the plastic bag and holds it up to his eyes. There is a tiny blue, green, yellow, red, and orange stri sea-horse swimming inside. Zissou says quietly:
A crayon pony-fish. Zissou looks down at Werner. ZISsou Thanks, pal. Zissou takes off his tie and puts it into his pocket. He on his collar and takes a deep breath. Klaus frowns.
You don’t look too good, Steve.  14. Zissou licks his hand and presses down his hair awkwardly rearranging his cowlicks. He looks to Klaus.
How about now? Klaus hesitates. Zissou sees the elderly man in the safar jacket lurking behind him. He snaps:
What do you need, old man? The elderly man thrusts a photograph and a pen into Zisso hands.

Could you sign this, please? Zissou looks at the photograph. It is a picture of a youn blond Zissou underwater pointing a spear-gun at a black s with four blue eyes and yellow ink. A title across the bo says Shadow Creatures of the Lurisia Archipelago. Zissou signs the photograph.

And this. The elderly man hands Zissou another photograph. It is a picture of two divers with movie cameras filming a swarm writhing sea-cobras. A title across the bottom says The Battling Eels of Antibes. Zissou signs the photograph.

And this. The elderly man hands Zissou another photograph. It is a picture of a younger Zissou running at a full sprint alongside a black panther with white spots. A title acros the bottom says Island Cats! Zissou frowns.
How many you got there? Zissou sees that there are about twenty-five more photogr in the elderly man’s hand. He frowns.
Just forge the rest of them, will you?  15.
(hesitates) But I could’ve done that --

Get lost. Get out of here. The elderly man looks startled. He walks away. Zissou sees Eleanor standing alone outside the window loo into the harbor. He raps on the glass. Eleanor turns to l at him. Zissou shrugs. He waves to her. Eleanor waves bac sadly. She holds up a pill of her own and swallows it wit drink of whiskey. Zissou smiles.

Zissou and Eleanor come out of the theatre and walk down red carpet along the front steps surrounded by a mob of f and paparazzi snapping pictures, jostling, and yelling. Drakoulias, Klaus, Ogata, Pelé, Renzo, and Vikram follow them. Zissou is blank and silent. He puts on his red cap. A tall man in a polo shirt motions to Zissou.
Hey, Steve! How come you’re not sitting shiva for your friend Esteban? Zissou stops. He looks at the man.
What’d you say? Pause. The man shrugs and says with a slight smile:

Who you going to kill in Part 2? The man points a pocket camera at Zissou and takes a snapshot. Zissou stares at the man. He lunges through the crowd and reaches for the man’s throat. The man dodges awkwardly and clips Zissou across the mouth with his came Klaus and Drakoulias pull Zissou back. The mob goes into panic. Eleanor lights a cigarette. Zissou moves away, disoriented, holding his hand against mouth. A line of blood runs down the side of his chin. He looks at his sea-horse. The plastic bag is leaking.  16. Zissou takes a glass of champagne out of someone’s hand. empties it onto the ground. He pours the sea-horse and th rest of the water into the glass. He walks down the steps a daze, holding the glass carefully above the crowd.

A party on-board the Belafonte moored in the bay. Pelé si on deck playing a David Bowie song on a guitar. The guest are writers, artists, scientists, socialites, movie stars fashion models, government officials, and business tycoon Three motorboats flying Team Zissou flags wait tied along the ship. The lights of hotels and casinos glimmer on the shore.

A living room with faux-wood Formica walls and tables for backgammon, chess, and cards. Drakoulias sits in a red vi armchair. Eleanor is on a red vinyl sofa playing solitair There are strips of duct tape to repair rips in the vinyl Zissou has a swollen cut on his lip. He paces around the room. Klaus and Wolodarsky play backgammon in the corner. Drakoulias holds a glass of sherry. The party continues outside.
Larry Amin’s flying back to Mecca tonight to see if he can make the numbers work. He‘1l have an answer for us in ten days.
(immediately) Tell him we need to know by Sunday.
(hesitates) Why would I do that, my darling?
(shrugs) To call his bluff, dammit. To light a fire under his ass.
My darling, we haven’t made a hit documentary in nine years. Let’s not fuck with Larry Amin. Explain it to him, Eleanor.  17.
(flipping a card) He understands. Amin has to make a projection of the world grosses to see if he can get a tax break and run it through his output deal.
I don’t understand -- but I can tell it’s bullshit. Eleanor looks to Zissou. Zissou stares down at her cards.
You can put the three on the four. Pause. Eleanor moves the three of clubs onto the four of hearts.
Werner, what are you doing? Werner stands on a table in the corner of the room with h sleeve rolled up to his shoulder and his arm reaching for turtle at the bottom of an aquarium filled with water.

Be careful, Werner. That’s a snapper. Werner lifts the turtle out of the aquarium. It has red a yellow markings and a slightly broken shell. He flips it over. The word Albert is written on the bottom of the tur in magic marker. He drops it back into the tank. Silence. Zissou shrugs.

Well, if you’1l excuse me, I’m going to go on an overnight drunk, and in ten days I’m going to head out to find the shark that ate my friend and destroy it. Anyone who wants to join me is more than welcome. Zissou goes out the door.
The party is in full swing. Zissou puts on his red cap an walks purposefully toward the bar. The pilot from the upp balcony at the screening approaches him and says reluctan  18.
Captain Zissou? I’m sorry to bother you. I’m Ned Plimpton. ZISsoU (distracted) OK, man.
My mother was Katherine Plimpton. Zissou stops. He looks confused.
You're kidding.
No.
(hesitates) How is she?
She died last month.
(pause) Oh. I‘m sorry. Holy shit. She was -- Hm. A long, complicated moment passes between Zissou and Ned. Zissou says quietly:
I've heard of you. Zissou and Ned step out of the crowd and stand together n to the railing of the ship.
I don’t know if it’s true, by the way. Do you?
No, I don’t.
I hadn’t seen her in maybe thirty years. (pause) I guess it’s too late now. Ned nods. Silence.  19.
She never contacted me, you know.
Yes, I see.
You're supposed to be my son, right?
I don’t know. But I did want to meet you, just in case.

I appreciate that. Zissou pats Ned gently on the shoulder. He takes a deep breath. He nods. Ned locks at him with a hopeful expressi Zissou suddenly finds himself struggling to hold back his emotions. He looks up at the sky. He shakes his head.

I'll be right back. Don’t go away. Zissou turns and walks quickly among the party-goers. The try to get his attention, but he does not respond. He cli a set of stairs. He goes to the prow of the ship. He reac into his pocket, takes out a joint, and lights it. He stands alone, smoking, and looks out at the dark ocean
Zissou coming back to Ned, who has not moved an inch.
Sorry about that. You’re catching me with one foot off the merry-go-round tonight.
Oh, that’s all right. I don’t want to take up any more of your time. Thank you very much for talking to me. Drakoulias grabs Zissou and Ned by their arms. He is now slightly drunk.
We'll find a way, mate.
I know we will.  20. Drakoulias hugs Zissou.

I just had a lovely chat with Si Perlman, and he wants to make a big to-do of the Oceanographic Explorer article and possibly give you the cover, so do be nice to this girl Miss Winslett- Richardson. Apparently, she worships you, and we dearly need the press. Zissou nods and motions to Ned.
This is probably my son, Ned. We just met.
(pause) Ah. Delightful.

A long table under an awning at the back of the ship. It filled with people, including Drakoulias, talking loudly drinking. Eleanor sits with her legs crossed holding a champagne cocktail and smoking a cigarette. Zissou stands above her with Ned just behind them.
Obviously, this all comes unexpectedly. You never knew about it. But --
I'd heard the story -- and you told me it wasn’t true.

Well, it probably isn’t. We’re talking ancient history here. But, anyway, his mother just died, plus we’re having some problems -- Eleanor gives Zissou a cold look. Ned jams his hands into pockets and shifts uncomfortably.
-- and I just think it’s a very special opportunity for all of us. Especially him. He needs this deal.  21.
(quickly) OK. Bring him over.
(hesitates) Well, he’s right here. Zissou points to Ned. Eleanor turns around and sees him. bows awkwardly. Eleanor looks flustered. She says simply:
I’m sorry. How do you do?
Zissou and Ned sit in the dark at the controls of the shi Lights blink on the consoles. Zissou smokes a joint.

No, it went OK. There’s just a lot in play here that’s got nothing to do with you, in terms of me and Eleanor. Zissou hands the joint to Ned. Ned hesitates, then takes puff. He exhales. ZISsou So tell me. What do you do? Pause. Ned points to his pilot’s cap.
I’m a pilot. For Air Kentucky. Co-pilot, actually.
Air Kentucky. Yeah. I don’t know that one.
(nods) We hub out of Louisville.

Oh, sure. There’s some pretty country around those parts. Land-locked. Can I get that number back over here for a second? Zissou points to the joint in Ned’s hand. Ned quickly han it back to Zissou.  22.
I beg your pardon. Zissou nods and smokes.

I have to tell you, I’ve been a member of the Zissou Society since I was eleven. Ned shows Zissou a Team Zissou ring on his finger. It is old and looks like it came out of a cereal box. Zissou lo at it and says with admiration:
Well, I’11 be dammed. Look at that. Zissou offers the joint back to Ned.
You want to kill this?
Frankly, I’d better not. I don’t usually try grass. Ned takes an old-fashioned pipe out of his jacket pocket. lights it with a match, takes a puff, and smiles at Zisso Zissou shakes his head.
Are you putting me on? Is this what you’re really like?
(hesitates} In what sense? Pause. Zissou nods.
OK. I buy it. Zissou picks up his model of the Belafonte and holds it i his hands.
Let me tell you about my boat.

A life-sized cross-section of the entire ship anchored in shallow waters. The hull is rusted along the water-line a needs a coat of paint. It is day, and the sky is pink. Zi  23. stands on deck with a fishing pole in his hands. People m among the cabins inside. There are schools of fish, coral and seaweed below. The camera takes us from one area to t next as Zissou describes the facilities in voice-over:

The Belafonte was a long-range sub-hunter during the second world war, which we bought from the U.S. Navy for $900,000. This is my mentor, Lord Mandrake. He's dead now. A silver-nitrate photograph of a dashing old man hangs on wall of the dining room. In the picture, the man stands o beach dressed all in white with his trouser legs rolled-u The camera booms down two levels to a completely blue-til Spa on the lowest deck. Steam fills the air. A sturdy, No woman in her sixties gives Klaus a violent massage.

The sauna was designed by an engineer from the Chinese space program, and we keep a Swedish masseuse on staff. We move quickly past a laboratory with a large, colorful periodic table hanging from the wall. Wolodarsky sits on stool nocdling on a Casio keyboard and a cheap drum machi A beaker of orange liquid bubbles on a Bunsen burner. Zis says dismissively:

Here’s where we do all our different science projects and experiments and so on. We arrive at the kitchen. There is a fancy, new dishwashe computerized refrigerator, and a digital toaster-oven. Th wine cellar is twice the size of the laboratory. A cook i Happy Birthday, Ogata! across the top of a cake.

This is the kitchen, which contains probably some of the most technologically advanced equipment on the ship. The next cabin is lined with books from floor to ceiling every wall, with a Dewey decimal system card-catalogue. T is a metal rack displaying a twenty-five volume collectio Zissou Society books on various, esoteric undersea creatu and phenomena: Tragedy of the Red Octopus, The Sexual Maturity of the Moonfish, The Arctic Night-lights. They a all written by Eleanor Zissou, and she sits behind the ra correcting a set of proofs and smoking a brown cigarette.  24. ZISsou (V.0.) Eleanor put together a top-notch research library for us, with a complete, first- edition set of the Life Aquatic companion series. We go to a sound-proofed room the size of a closet. Vikra sits inside behind a glass partition. He wears headphones Renzo operates a tape recorder. There is also a flat-bed editing console and an accumulation of out-dated film developing machines.
We process our own rushes and keep a cutting room on-board so we can do an assembly while we're shooting. There are three little beeps before Vikram speaks into a microphone in a panicked voice:

I can’t find them! Renzo murmurs some mild approval and presses a button. We move to a metal sphere with portholes all over it connect to the bottom of the ship. Ogata is inside. He looks out his face pressed against the glass. ZISsou (V.0.) This is the observation bubble, which I thought up in a dream, actually. There are two white dolphins with cameras and electronic attached to them swimming underwater alongside the vessel They have pink eyes.

Two albino scouts swim with the ship. They’re supposedly very intelligent, although I’ve never seen any evidence of it. We move past the screw and rudder back up into the ship. motor looks old and jerry-rigged, with a severely rusted warped section of rods and valves, which leak into a pan.

Here’s the engine room. The bearing- casings aren’t supposed to look like that, but we can‘t afford to fix them this year.  25. The main deck is outfitted with an array of weather-beate equipment, two cranes, and a helicopter landing deck. Pel sits in a chair tuning his guitar.

Topside, we’ve got the bridge, the mini- sub, an old chopper, and all kinds of radar and sonar and underwater movie gadgets. A submersible vessel on deck was once called Jacqueline, that word has been crossed-out, and Deep Search has been printed below it.
What happened to Jacqueline?
(bittersweet) She didn’t really love me. All the lights in the ship dim suddenly, and the light of pink sky and the blue water gently fades to black.
The next morning. A converted palazzo behind a church. A brass plaque next to the door says Explorers Club.

The great hall. There are paintings of adventurers on the walls: big-game hunters, arctic explorers, archaeologists astronauts, aviators, etc. Under a stuffed and mounted swordfish, there are portraits of three oceanographers.
